title: VC Daily: What Is the Future of iBuying in Real Estate?
text:
DCM principal David Cheng said: "The most exciting investment opportunities are net new experiences that are completely digitally native as opposed to shifting offline experiences to digital."

Multiple Capital venture partner Michael Jackson said that Facebook's bet (and the success of gaming platforms like Roblox) reinforces investments in AR/VR and gaming that have been going on for years.

Guru Chahal, partner at Lightspeed Venture Partners, said: "To me, the most interesting metaverse opportunities lie at the ‘enablement' layers—interoperability, identity and portability, commerce, and of course infra performance and scaling."

This week's question: Does Zillow's exit from the home-flipping business—which it said was due to an algorithm to buy and sell homes not working as planned—have implications for real-estate tech startups that have built businesses based on the so-called iBuying model?

Please email responses to marc.vartabedian@wsj.com.

And now on to the news...

Top News

Electric-truck startup Nikola Corp. will likely pay $125 million to settle a regulatory investigation into allegedly misleading statements made by its founder and former executive chairman, The Wall Street Journal reports. Nikola disclosed the development Thursday in a securities filing that says the company plans to seek reimbursement for the penalty from its founder, Trevor Milton, who was indicted on fraud charges in July. Nikola was one of several transportation-focused firms that went public in 2020 through a merger with a blank-check firm known as a special-purpose acquisition company, or SPAC.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has closely scrutinized the SPAC market, which allowed many young, pre-revenue companies to go public at high valuations.

Nikola said the deal with the SEC isn't final and needs to be approved by the agency's commissioners. The company didn't disclose whether the settlement would involve fraud or lesser charges.

$1 Billion

The amount Alphabet Inc.'s Google has invested in futures-exchange giant CME Group Inc. (WSJ)

Federal Cybersecurity Directive Spotlights Aging Computer Systems

Many of the cybersecurity gaps outlined in a new White House directive that calls on federal agencies to patch hundreds of online vulnerabilities stem from the government's aging computer systems, current and former federal tech chiefs, lawmakers and industry analysts say. But ongoing efforts to upgrade these systems tend to get bogged down by budget restrictions, chronic talent shortages and a revolving door of agency information-technology leaders.

BTS, the K-Pop Band, Dives Into NFTs to Sell Digital Trading Cards

BTS is getting into NFTs. The boy-band sensation from South Korea is planning to sell digital cards of its band members that can be collected or traded, similar to the limited-edition physical photo cards fans already hoard. But the digital cards will move when tapped on and play music or show the bandmates talking. No date was given for when the NFTs will be launched.

Sustainable Business Forum

WSJ Pro is hosting the Sustainable Business Forum on Nov. 17. The program includes an innovation showcase with AB InBev, Keurig Dr Pepper and City Developments Ltd., and a presentation by Jonah Goldman, managing director at Breakthrough Energy. Register here.

Industry News

Funds

Nauta Capital held the final close of its oversubscribed fifth fund at €190 million ($219 million) to continue making seed and Series A investments in business-to-business software companies based mostly in the U.K., Spain and Germany. Within the past year, Nauta Capital participated in funding rounds for startups including chatbot builder Landbot and Zephr, which helps media companies increase their subscription revenue.

Emerson committed $100 million to its venture capital arm to advance the development of disruptive discrete automation services, environmentally-sustainable technologies and industrial software. Emerson Ventures aims to invest in four to six early-stage startups per year over the next five years.

Social Impact Capital closed its first fund with $42 million in commitments to invest in companies focused on climate change, health, supply chains and food systems. In June, the firm's inaugural investment, OpenInvest, was acquired by JP Morgan. Recently, two portfolio companies reached unicorn status: Prometheus Fuels and Andela.

People

New Enterprise Associates appointed Michele Park as partner based in the firm's Menlo Park, Calif., office. She joins NEA after 15 years as an investor at Clarus Ventures.

VCP Ventures said Emily Sharko joined the firm as partner and chief operating officer. She previously held the same positions at Pine Brook Partners.

Digital patient-communication startup Well Health Inc. named Sean Kelly as chief medical officer. He was most recently CMO at Imprivata. Santa Barbara, Calif.-based Well Health is backed by investors including Lead Edge Capital, Martin Ventures, Jackson Square Ventures, Health Velocity Capital and Freestyle Capital.

Exits

Agricultural-insights company Sentera acquired Insight Sensing, which delivers field-specific data to agronomists, for an undisclosed amount. St. Paul, Minn.-based Sentera said it raised a $25 million Series C round in June led by Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec and S2G Ventures.

AgentSync, a provider of tools and infrastructure for the insurance industry, acquired identity-verification platform Finvera for an undisclosed sum. In March, Denver-based AgentSync secured a $25 million Series A round from Elad Gil, Marc Benioff, Craft Ventures, Caffeinated Capital, Operator Collective and Nine Four Ventures.

Scale AI Inc., an artificial-intelligence application-development startup, purchased data-management platform SiaSearch for an undisclosed amount. San Francisco-based Scale AI in April said it raised a $325 million Series E round co-led by Dragoneer Investment Group, Greenoaks Capital Partners and Tiger Global Management.

New Money

Helion, an Everett, Wash.-based startup focused on generating zero-carbon electricity from fusion, closed a $500 million Series E round. Lead investor Sam Altman was joined by Dustin Moskovitz, Mithril Capital and Capricorn Investment Group in the new funding.

HoneyBook Inc., a San Francisco-based platform for independent business owners to manage their client and cash flow, scored a $250 million Series E round, giving the company a valuation of $2.4 billion. Tiger Global Management led the funding, which included contributions from Durable Capital Partners, Norwest Venture Partners, Citi Ventures and OurCrowd.

Treasure Data, a Mountain View, Calif.-based enterprise customer-data platform, picked up a $234 million investment. SoftBank Corp. led the round, which included additional support from Carbide Ventures.

Cloudbeds, a San Diego-based developer of hospitality-management software, raised $150 million in Series D funding. New investor SoftBank Vision Fund 2 led the round, which included participation from Echo Street Capital Management, Walleye Capital, Viking Global Investors, PeakSpan Capital and Counterpart Ventures.

Mythical Games, a Los Angeles-based gaming-technology studio creating universal gaming ecosystems around playable NFTs, secured $150 million in Series C financing led by Andreessen Horowitz, bringing the company's valuation up to $1.25 billion. The round also included participation from D1 Capital, RedBird Capital, The Raine Group, 32 Equity, Mantis VC, OneTeam Partners, Javelin Partners, Struck Capital, Alumni Ventures, Binance, FTX and others.

Papa, a Miami-based provider of companionship and support for older adults, families and other vulnerable populations, snagged $150 million in Series D funding at a valuation of $1.4 billion. Led by SoftBank Vision Fund 2, the round included participation from TCG, Tiger Global Management, Canaan Partners, Initialized Capital and Seven Seven Six.

Reltio, a Redwood Shores, Calif.-based data-management startup, collected $120 million in new funding, valuing the company at $1.7 billion. Brighton Park Capital led the investment, which saw participation from Crosslink Capital, NewView Capital, RPS Ventures, Sapphire Ventures and .406 Ventures. Mike Gregoire, partner and co-founder of Brighton Park, will join Reltio's board.

Fountain, a San Francisco-based provider of an applicant-tracking system for companies hiring hourly workers, nabbed an $85 million Series C round. SoftBank Vision Fund 2 led the new funding, which saw participation from DCM, Origin Ventures, Commerce Ventures, SemperVirens Venture Capital, Uncork Capital, B Capital Group and Mirae Asset Venture Investment.

PlateletBio, a Watertown, Mass.-based cell-therapy platform, raised $75.5 million in Series B financing. New investors SymBiosis Capital Management, K2 HealthVentures and Oxford Finance were joined by previous backers Ziff Capital Partners and Qiming Venture Partners in the round. Chidozie Ugwumba, managing partner of SymBiosis, joined the board.

Yellowbrick Data, a data-warehousing company with headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., London and Hong Kong, completed a $75 million Series C1 round from investors including Citadel, Third Point Ventures, Menlo Ventures, Next47, DFJ Growth, Threshold Ventures, GV and IVP.

Sama, a San Francisco-based artificial-intelligence training-data company, fetched a $70 million Series B round. Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec led the investment, which included support from First Ascent Ventures, Salesforce Ventures, Vistara Capital Partners and existing investors.

PubNub Inc., a San Francisco-based API platform, grabbed $65 million in Series E funding. Lead investor The Raine Group was joined by Sapphire Ventures, Scale Ventures and others in the round. Raine's Christopher Donini and Kevin Linker will join PubNub's board.

Tech News

Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin loses suit over NASA moon lander

Ex-Rivian executive's discrimination suit airs questions about business plans as IPO looms

FTV Capital invests $160 million in Plate IQ

IBM spinoff Kyndryl starts quest for growth

AT&T, Verizon to delay 5G rollout over FAA's airplane-safety concerns

Hertz will have to wait for Teslas, just like other buyers

Around the Web

Bird's top VC went from scooter skeptic to convert ahead of SPAC deal (Bloomberg)
